ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about general chemistry concepts.
I got better at solving chemistry problems, particularly those involving dimensional analysis / stoichiometry.
This class provided me with a solid knowledge of the fundamentals of general chemistry, from aqueous chemistry to thermochemistry. I developed a thorough understanding of key concepts of chemistry.
I felt this was a good general chemistry course. I learned much of this material in high school, but I thought the topics were well-organized and explained.
basic chemistry and analysis skills
First half of general chemistry.

I learned a lot about different chemistry techniques and ways to approach problems from stoichiometry to molecular geometry. This course also helped me to reason through problems when the necessary approach was not apparent.
I furthered my chemistry knowledge from high school and refreshed my skills in the subject matter.
i learned basic chemistry topics, such as redox reactions and atomic principles.
Allowed myself to garner a foundational understanding of general chemistry principles in interactive setting

Learning to see the world differently through the lens of Chemistry--It definitely felt like learning a new language! I had a very basic foundation from a year or so of foundational high school chemistry (GCSEs), but the scope of this course was far beyond that and I learned many new skills. There is actually quite a lot of physics and maths in the course (the physics parts are, in my opinion, the most interesting). You learn about everything from gas behaviour to quantum theory and specifically how they relate to chemistry. A fantastic introduction to the core concepts of the field that prioritises a new way of thinking rather than wrote learning of equations and case studies.
chemical familiarity, stoichiometry, thermal chemistry, ease with measurements, etc
Learned the basics of chemistry, topics including thermodynamics, etc.
Problem solving and analytical approach.
Basic to intermediate chem, basic thermo
We learned the basics of chemistry from atomic structure through thermochemistry.
I learned a lot about the chemistry that goes on in real world aspects. I understand a lot of concepts that were unclear from my high school chem.
I guess to think about life on a micro scale.

Course covers the basics of chemistry such as balancing chemical equations, redox, acids and bases, molecular structures and intermolecular forces. I learned how to properly read and extract relevant information from a periodic table.
A greater understanding of chemistry and its origins, in addition, to its influence on modern thought
Taking this course helped my problem-solving skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The pacing of this course, with midterms interspersed between weeks of lessons and at least one week after the last lesson on the midterm, was difficult to keep up with. It's really hard to learn new material while also trying to study for a midterm with no grace period. I'm not sure if there's a fix for this, though.

Strengths - Good pace. Useful homework problems.

Weaknesses - Practice exams were not representative of exam difficulty.

The course was adapted very well to the virtual format. Dr. Cooper did an excellent job of preparing engaging lectures, providing numerous practice problems to keep the class engaged, and addressing questions both during and after class. 
I honestly can't think of any glaring weaknesses of the class.

The weekly workload is pretty high, since there are two problem sets and weekly quizzes. It would have been nice to have a bit more breathing room around the midterm exams in terms of problem set due dates.
great course, would be much better in person but well designed for virtual learning

1. Very well-structured
2. Lots of practice material

The way the course was structured allowed for a clear transition between the materials in the chapters. In addition, each chapter built upon concepts we learned prior. The sapling psets and learning curves allowed for a significant amount of practice in each topic before the exams. Finally, the practice exams were extremely helpful.

The strengths of this course are the weekly homework assignments and the discussion sections, as these forced me to stay engaged with the course and helped prevent me from falling behind. A weakness of this course was the virtual format, but this was inevitable because of the pandemic.
strengths- professor cooper is very nice. weakensses- i think the grading is unfair. if we don't put units we get a whole point off even if we did the entire problem right until that point.
Caring and passionate professor made the course very interactive and always peaked the students curiosity

If you haven't taken IB/A level/AP chemistry BE PREPARED. You will probably be in a class with quite a few who have. This was a big challenge because while the instruction was extremely clear, they're far more likely to mop up a good grade while doing less work--it would have been nice to also reward students on their improvement over time. I found the Sapling homeworks EXTREMELY helpful in solidifying concepts, although occasionally we had to independently learn concepts that weren't covered in lecture/were skimmed over. The sections were fairly gruelling as some took place before the due date of the homework, meaning we hadn't really had enough time to ruminate over the ideas and their application. However, content was consistently interesting and accessible. Seriously, this class is super fascinating! This class was a fairly weighty time commitment - three very dense lectures, a learning curve hw, a pretty tricky (but not too long) PSET, and a 1hr section. Additionally, we had three midterms (during the weekend! Which objectively sucks) and a final (with no "ignore the lowest grade" policy). Each to their own, but it isn't the most forgiving class especially if you're taking a 5+ credit semester.
strengths: starts at the beginning of chemistry, assumes very little pre-established knowledge.

Too many assessments were present throughout the whole course with weekly quizzes, three midterms, one final, problem-sets, and learning curves. At some point in the semester, it started to feel like learning was obstructed with trying to submit all the assignments.
Great Professor, but I did not love sapling learning site
The strengths are that Professor Cooper is an incredible teacher. He is excellent at explaining the material to students, and is very organized with the pace of the course.
Weakness: You must be doing well in all of the tests, there is no chance to make a comeback if you don't start off strong.
Basic enough information for someone with minimal interaction with chemistry in high school.

Course is well-organized and instructors/TFs are very knowledgable. However, during certain points of the semester when workload in general is high, it would be helpful if all the assignments were more spaced out.
Being online it was easy to get distracted and consider the course to be boring. I had to go back and rewatch the recordings.
Strengths were the teaching format and the timing of the lecture classes and the explanations of the content.
I would have liked to do more problems like those on exams on problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lecture seemed to transfer well to Zoom.
It was useful that virtual lectures were recorded.

I think the class was extremely successful in the virtual format. The class did exactly what it set out to do, which was to provide students with an in-depth understanding of general chemistry in a live, virtual format. I particularly appreciated the homework assignments, which allowed us between three and an infinite number of attempts to work on various problems and really strengthen our understanding of the material. I also found the discussion sections extremely helpful to do some extra practice with the material and make sure that I sufficiently understood the content covered in class.
This course worked well online. I imagine it would be nearly identical in person.
the live lectures were great but the discussion sections could be a little more engaging
Sapling was a very great tool. I really like that live lecture recordings were available after class.

The virtual discussion sections definitely succeeded, especially working on practice problems and group quizzes in smaller breakout rooms. This helped me work with other students and receive feedback and advice from my peers.
discussion sections were a bit hard during covid as it was hard to interact with one another.
Live lecture was great
Live lectures were good
The recorded lectures were all excellent and I am glad that they were recorded. The professor was also very responsive out of class with any questions.
virtual lectures were efficient, recorded lectures were very much appreciated.
The virtual and recorded nature of this course made me personally less engaged with the material.
The sections were useful

I think that the recorded lectures were good and the discussion section was a good way to engage the students, but offering more office hours at a variety of times with TFs would have been very helpful.

The professor was very engaging so the live lectures worked. Having the option to watch them later on also was super helpful. Hopefully Yale keeps recording lectures and posting them for future reference.

The recordings of the virtual lectures were helpful in reviewing the material for exams or trying to clear up misconceptions. Furthermore, the virtual office hours allowed students to drop in when there were questions instead of having to carve out time from busy schedules for in-person attendance. 

I think these practices should continue when in-person classes return.
Class engagement was a little low but otherwise I went well in the class
I think the discussion sections were helpful, especially when we were forced to do the problems ourselves instead of just following along with the TA..

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would not recommend this course to another student if it is not a prerequisite for their major.

If you are taking this class, it's probably because you have to take it. That being said, Dr. Cooper is an excellent professor and the course was not too difficult or boring. The problem sets prepare you well for the exams, and I feel like I have a good base for moving further on in chemistry.

Yes. It overlaps with several other branches of science - physics, biology, even astronomy. But it also just provides solid, basic science knowledge. If you're going to take one science class at Yale, take Gen Chem I.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone looking for a good introduction to chemistry. All the concepts are explained very clearly, and the weekly discussions reinforce all the material taught in lectures. The workload is very manageable and the weekly problem sets and quizzes provide regular, low-stress opportunities to practice relevant problems and build a strong understanding of the material.
I would recommend this course to anyone who needs a general chemistry requirement.
yes a great starting chemistry course to build off of
Absolutely. It was a very fun way to learn general chemistry.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student.  I learned a lot about different chemistry techniques. In addition, we learned a lot about the rationale behind the equations used.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student who would like to learn chemistry or further their knowledge of the subject. The course is set up in a way that can help even those who are less scientifically inclined learn chemistry in a very clear and understandable way.
Yes, if you need it as a requirement.
Of course. The Professor is very understanding
Yes I would, great professor and everybody needs a foundation of chemistry in their life
Yes, it's a great requirement to take (especially with Cooper!) as it's very engaging content-wise. There's just quite a bit of regular testing--it's no walk in the park.
yes, if chemistry is a requirement
If you want to fulfill a science credit, no. Take it only if you need this class for your prerequisites and major or are interested in learning chemistry.
If they do not have to take it due to certain pre-requisites, I would not recommend.
Yes
Yes, even if they are not a chemist. I think this course gives you a basic understanding of many chemistry concepts.

If you are interested in life sciences, this course is required. In general, this course offers a great overview of the basics of chemistry, however for non-majors, the number of assignments and three lectures a week makes this harder than a gut.
The course was interesting and Professor Cooper was nice
Yes it was a very fun class to be in and there were a lot of people I engaged with.
Yes I would, Professor Cooper is a great teacher!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was also a virtual discussion section.
Weekly virtual discussion section
We also participated in weekly discussion sections to strengthen our understanding of the concepts covered in class.
recorded lecture
Live, virtual lecture and live virtual discussion session
Sapling
The class included a combination of live virtual lectures and virtual discussion sections.
live discussion section
Sapling Learning
Every lecture was recorded and posted in the media library as well for students that were unable to attend
Lectures were live virtual but were recorded and added to canvas.
live virtual section
Had discussion sections
It was a combination of recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.
Online hmwk
There was a recorded lecture in combination with a required discussion section every week lead by a TF.
Also had recorded lectures of live virtual sessions.
Virtual discussion section
Recorded lecture/live virtual lecture; virtual discussion sections.
live virtual lecture that was also recorded
Online discussion section and review sessions.
Recorded lectures as well
